content.title: Femoropopliteal Bypass
content.definition: Surgical bypass from the common femoral artery to the popliteal artery (above or below knee) using autogenous vein or prosthetic graft, circumventing occlusive disease in the superficial femoral artery. A mainstay of open revascularization for peripheral arterial disease.

key_concepts.description: Autogenous great saphenous vein (GSV) is gold standard; significantly better patency than prosthetic, especially below-knee. If GSV unavailable: arm veins > prosthetic with vein cuff
Above-knee popliteal: better patency, prosthetic acceptable; Below-knee popliteal: vein strongly preferred, prosthetic patency poor. Choice based on disease extent and runoff
Above-knee: 80-85% at 5 years; Below-knee: 65-80% at 5 years. Superior to prosthetic at all levels
Above-knee PTFE: 50-70% at 5 years; Below-knee PTFE: 30-50% at 5 years. Prosthetic + vein cuff improves below-knee results
Reversed: vein removed, reversed to allow flow (valves don't obstruct); In-situ: vein left in place, valves lysed with valvulotome. Similar patency; in-situ may have better size match
Adequate inflow essential; iliac stenosis should be treated before or with bypass; CFA should have good pulse or be endarterectomized
Runoff vessels (tibial arteries) affect patency; better runoff = better outcomes; may need distal extension if popliteal is also diseased
Miller cuff, Taylor patch, or boot anastomotic modification interposing vein at distal anastomosis; improves below-knee prosthetic patency; reduces compliance mismatch
Duplex surveillance at 1, 3, 6, 12 months then annually; detect failing grafts (stenosis) before occlusion; allows intervention to maintain patency
Early (<30 days): technical error, hypercoagulability; Intermediate (1-24 months): myointimal hyperplasia; Late (>24 months): progression of atherosclerosis

content.statement: Femoropopliteal Bypass is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Femoropopliteal-Bypass that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Femoropopliteal Bypass helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Femoropopliteal Bypass include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Femoropopliteal Bypass.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

learning_objectives: Know patency differences above-knee vs below-knee
Recognize the role of vein cuff for prosthetic grafts
Apply surveillance protocols for early detection of failing grafts
clinical_pearls: Vein is gold standard - always use if available
Above-knee: prosthetic acceptable; Below-knee: vein strongly preferred
5-year patency: AK vein 80-85%, BK vein 65-80%, BK prosthetic 30-50%
Vein cuff improves below-knee prosthetic patency
Surveillance detects failing grafts BEFORE occlusion (salvageable)
common_mistakes: Using prosthetic below-knee when vein is available
Not using vein cuff with below-knee prosthetic

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
